The light beam is parallel to the central symmetry axis OO'.
The light beam is incident on the outer surface of the hemisphere.
The refractive index of the glass is n = √2.
The outer radius of the hemisphere is R' = √2R.
The inner radius of the hemisphere is R.
The light beam undergoes refraction at the outer surface.
The angle of incidence is 0 degrees because the beam is parallel to the axis.
The angle of refraction is calculated using Snell's law: n1 sin θ1 = n2 sin θ2.
Since n1 = 1 (air) and n2 = √2, sin θ2 = sin θ1 / √2.
The angle of refraction θ2 is 45 degrees.
The light beam travels along a path that makes a 45-degree angle with the axis.
The light beam reaches the inner surface at a distance d from the axis.
The distance d is equal to the inner radius R.
A light-blocking plate with radius d = R is needed to block the light.
The radius d of the light shield is R.
